member.name: T:OpenTracing.IScope
member.summary:
A formalizes the activation and deactivation of a , usually from a CPU standpoint.
Many times a will be extant (in that has not been called) despite being in a non-runnable state from a CPU/scheduler standpoint. For instance, a representing the child side of an RPC will be unfinished but blocked on IO while the RPC is still outstanding. A defines when a given is scheduled and on the path.
Calling marks the end of the active period for the current thread and , updating the in the process.

member.name: P:OpenTracing.IScope.Span
member.summary: The that's been scoped by this .

member.name: T:OpenTracing.IScopeManager
P:OpenTracing.IScopeManager.Active
member.summary:
Return the currently active which can be used to access the currently active .
If there is an non-null , its wrapped becomes an implicit parent of any newly-created at time (rather than at time).
member.returns: The active , or null if none could be found.

member.name: M:OpenTracing.IScopeManager.Activate(OpenTracing.ISpan,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Make a instance active.
member.param: The that should become the .
Whether span should automatically be finished when is called.
member.returns: A instance to control the end of the active period for the . It is a programming error to neglect to call on the returned instance.

Like , but with an explicit timestamp.
CAUTIONARY NOTE: not all Tracer implementations support key:value log fields end-to-end. Caveat emptor.

key:value log fields. Tracer implementations should support string, int, double, and bool values; some may also support arbitrary objects.

member.name: M:OpenTracing.ISpan.Log(System.String)
member.summary:
Record an event at the current timestamp. Shorthand for
span.Log(new Dictionary<string, object> { { "event", event } });
member.param: The event value; often a stable identifier for a moment in the span lifecycle.

member.name: M:OpenTracing.ISpan.Log(System.DateTimeOffset,System.String)
member.summary:
Record an event at a specific timestamp. Shorthand for
span.Log(timestamp, new Dictionary<string, object> { { "event", event } });
member.param: The explicit timestamp for the log record. Must be greater than or equal to the span's start timestamp.
The event value; often a stable identifier for a moment in the span lifecycle.

member.name: M:OpenTracing.ISpan.SetBaggageItem(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Sets a baggage item in the span (and its ) as a key:value pair. Baggage enables powerful distributed context propagation functionality where arbitrary application data can be carried along the full path of request execution throughout the system. Note 1: Baggage is only propagated to the future (recursive) children of this . Note 2: Baggage is sent in-band with every subsequent local and remote calls, so this feature must be used with care.

member.name: M:OpenTracing.ISpan.GetBaggageItem(System.String)
member.summary: The value of the baggage item identified by , or null if no such item could be found.

member.name: M:OpenTracing.ISpan.SetOperationName(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the string name for the logical operation this span represents.

member.name: M:OpenTracing.ISpan.Finish
member.summary:
Sets the end timestamp to now and records the span.
With the exception of calls to , this should be the last call made to the span instance. Future calls to are defined as noops, and future calls to methods other than lead to undefined behavior (likely an exception).

member.name: M:OpenTracing.ISpan.Finish(System.DateTimeOffset)
member.summary:
Sets an explicit end timestamp and records the span.
With the exception of calls to , this should be the last call made to the span instance, and to do otherwise leads to undefined behavior.
member.param: An explicit finish timestamp.

Add a reference from the span being built to a distinct (usually parent) span. May be called multiple times to represent multiple such references.
If
the 's is not null, and
no explicit references are added via , and
is not invoked,
... then an inferred reference is created to the when either or is invoked.
member.param: The reference type, typically one of the constants defined in .

member.name: M:OpenTracing.ISpanBuilder.StartActive
member.summary:
Same as with finishSpanOnDispose: true.
Returns a newly started and activated . The underlying span is finished automatically when the scope is disposed.
The returned supports using(). For example:
using (IScope scope = tracer.BuildSpan("...").StartActive()) { // (Do work) scope.Span.SetTag( ... ); // etc, etc } // Span finishes automatically on Dispose.
If
the 's is not null, and
no explicit references are added via , and
is not invoked,
... then an inferred reference is created to the when either or is invoked.

member.name: M:OpenTracing.ISpanBuilder.StartActive(System.Boolean)
member.param: Whether span should automatically be finished when is called.

member.name: M:OpenTracing.ISpanBuilder.Start
member.summary: Like , but the returned has not been registered via the .
member.returns: The newly-started span instance, which has *not* been automatically registered via the .

member.name: T:OpenTracing.ISpanContext
member.summary: represents span state that must propagate to descendant spans and across process boundaries. is logically divided into two pieces: (1) the user-level "Baggage" that propagates across span boundaries and (2) any Tracer-implementation-specific fields that are needed to identify or otherwise contextualize the associated span instance(e.g., a { trace_id, span_id, sampled } tuple).

member.name: P:OpenTracing.ISpanContext.TraceId
member.summary: Globally unique. Every span in a trace shares this ID.

member.name: P:OpenTracing.ISpanContext.SpanId
member.summary: Unique within a trace. Each span within a trace contains a different ID.

member.name: M:OpenTracing.ISpanContext.GetBaggageItems
member.returns: All zero or more baggage items propagating along with the associated span.

member.name: T:OpenTracing.LogFields
member.summary: The following log fields are recommended for instrumentors who are trying to capture more information about a logged event. Tracers may expose additional features based on these standardized data points.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.LogFields.ErrorKind
member.summary: The type or "kind" of an error (only for event="error" logs). E.g., "Exception", "OSError".

member.name: F:OpenTracing.LogFields.ErrorObject
member.summary: The actual object instance.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.LogFields.Event
member.summary: A stable identifier for some notable moment in the lifetime of a span. For instance, a mutex lock acquisition or release or the sorts of lifetime events in a browser page load described in the Performance.timing specification. E.g., from Zipkin, "cs", "sr", "ss", or "cr". Or, more generally, "initialized" or "timed out". For errors, "error".

member.name: F:OpenTracing.LogFields.Message
member.summary: A concise, human-readable, one-line message explaining the event. E.g., "Could not connect to backend", "Cache invalidation succeeded".

member.name: F:OpenTracing.LogFields.Stack
member.summary: A stack trace in platform-conventional format; may or may not pertain to an error.

example.code: at App.Program.SomeMethod() in C:\app\Program.cs:line 14 at App.Program.Main(String[] args) in C:\app\Program.cs:line 9

member.name: T:OpenTracing.Mock.MockTracer
member.summary:
makes it easy to test the semantics of OpenTracing instrumentation.
By using a as an implementation for unittests, a developer can assert that span properties and relationships with other spans are defined as expected by instrumentation code.
The MockTracerTests class has simple usage examples.

member.name: M:OpenTracing.Mock.MockTracer.#ctor(OpenTracing.Mock.IPropagator)
member.summary: Create a new that passes through any calls to and/or .

member.name: M:OpenTracing.Mock.MockTracer.Reset
member.summary:
Clear the queue.
Note that this does *not* have any effect on spans created by MockTracer that have not Finish()ed yet; those will still be enqueued in when they Finish().

member.name: M:OpenTracing.Mock.MockTracer.FinishedSpans
member.summary: Returns a copy of all Finish()ed MockSpans started by this MockTracer (since construction or the last call to ).

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Propagation.BuiltinFormats.TextMap
member.summary: The 'TextMap' format allows for arbitrary string-string dictionary encoding of state for and . Unlike , the builtin 'TextMap' format expresses no constraints on keys or values.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Propagation.BuiltinFormats.HttpHeaders
member.summary: The 'HttpHeaders' format allows for HTTP-header-compatible string-string dictionary encoding of state for and . I.e, keys written to the MUST be suitable for HTTP header keys (which are poorly defined but certainly restricted); and similarly for values (i.e., URL-escaped and "not too long").

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Propagation.BuiltinFormats.Binary
member.summary: The 'Binary' format allows for unconstrained byte encoding of state for and using a .

member.name: M:OpenTracing.Propagation.BuiltinFormats.Builtin`1.ToString
member.summary: Short name for built-in formats as they tend to show up in exception messages.

member.name: T:OpenTracing.Propagation.IBinary

member.summary: Sets the backing MemoryStream of an store.

T:OpenTracing.Propagation.ITextMap
member.summary: is a built-in carrier for and . ITextMap implementations allows Tracers to read and write key:value string pairs from arbitrary underlying sources of data.

member.summary: Puts a key:value pair into the ITextMap's backing store.

member.name: T:OpenTracing.Propagation.TextMapExtractAdapter
member.summary: A carrier for use with ONLY (it has no mutating methods). Note that the interface can be made to wrap around arbitrary data types (not just Dictionary<string, string> as illustrated here).

member.name: T:OpenTracing.Propagation.TextMapInjectAdapter
member.summary: A carrier for use with ONLY (it has no read methods). Note that the interface can be made to wrap around arbitrary data types (not just Dictionary<string, string> as illustrated here).

member.name: T:OpenTracing.References
member.summary: is essentially a namespace for the official OpenTracing reference types. References are used by to describe the relationships between spans.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.References.ChildOf
member.summary: See https://github.com/opentracing/specification/blob/master/specification.md#references-between-spans for more information about CHILD_OF references.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.References.FollowsFrom
member.summary: See https://github.com/opentracing/specification/blob/master/specification.md#references-between-spans for more information about FOLLOWS_FROM references.

member.name: T:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags
member.summary: The following span tags are recommended for instrumentors who are trying to capture more semantic information about the spans. Tracers may expose additional features based on these standardized data points. Tag names follow a general structure of namespacing.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.SpanKindServer
member.summary: A static readonlyant for setting the span kind to indicate that it represents a server span.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.SpanKindClient
member.summary: A static readonlyant for setting the span kind to indicate that it represents a client span.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.SpanKindProducer
member.summary: A static readonlyant for setting the span kind to indicate that it represents a producer span, in a messaging scenario.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.SpanKindConsumer
member.summary: A static readonlyant for setting the span kind to indicate that it represents a consumer span, in a messaging scenario.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.HttpUrl
member.summary: HttpUrl records the url of the incoming request.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.HttpStatus
member.summary: HttpStatus records the http status code of the response.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.HttpMethod
member.summary: HttpMethod records the http method. Case-insensitive.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.PeerHostIpv4
member.summary: PeerHostIpv4 records IPv4 host address of the peer.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.PeerHostIpv6
member.summary: PeerHostIpv6 records the IPv6 host address of the peer.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.PeerService
member.summary: PeerService records the service name of the peer.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.PeerHostname
member.summary: PeerHostname records the host name of the peer.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.PeerPort
member.summary: PeerPort records the port number of the peer.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.SamplingPriority
member.summary: SamplingPriority determines the priority of sampling this span.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.SpanKind
member.summary: SpanKind hints at the relationship between spans, e.g. client/server.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.Component
member.summary: Component is a low-cardinality identifier of the module, library, or package that is instrumented.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.Error
member.summary: Error indicates whether a span ended in an error state.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.DbType
member.summary: DbType indicates the type of Database. For any SQL database, "sql". For others, the lower-case database category, e.g. "cassandra", "hbase", or "redis".

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.DbInstance
member.summary: Database instance name. E.g., In java, if the jdbc.url="jdbc:mysql://127.0.0.1:3306/customers", instance name is "customers".

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.DbUser
member.summary: DbUser indicates the user name of Database, e.g. "readonly_user" or "reporting_user".

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.DbStatement
member.summary: DbStatement records a database statement for the given database type. For db.type="SQL", "SELECT FROM wuser_table". For db.type="redis", "SET mykey "WuValue"".

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Tag.Tags.MessageBusDestination
member.summary: MessageBusDestination records an address at which messages can be exchanged. E.g. A Kafka record has an associated "topic name" that can be extracted by the instrumented producer or consumer and stored using this tag.

member.name: T:OpenTracing.Util.AsyncLocalScope
member.summary: The is a simple implementation that relies on C#'s AsyncLocal/CallContext storage primitive.

member.name: T:OpenTracing.Util.AsyncLocalScopeManager
member.summary: The is a simple implementation that relies on C#'s AsyncLocal/CallContext storage primitive.

member.name: T:OpenTracing.Util.GlobalTracer
member.summary:
Global tracer that forwards all methods to another tracer that can be configured by calling .
The method should only be called once during the application initialization phase.
If the method is never called, the default is used.
Where possible, use some form of dependency injection (of which there are many) to access the instance. For vanilla application code, this is often reasonable and cleaner for all of the usual DI reasons.
That said, instrumentation for packages that are themselves statically configured (e.g., JDBC drivers) may be unable to make use of said DI mechanisms for access, and as such they should fall back on . By and large, OpenTracing instrumentation should always allow the programmer to specify a instance to use for instrumentation, though the is a reasonable fallback or default value.

member.name: F:OpenTracing.Util.GlobalTracer.s_instance
member.summary:
Singleton instance.
Since we cannot prevent people using as a constant, this guarantees that references obtained before, during or after initialization all behave as if obtained after initialization once properly initialized.
As a minor additional benefit it makes it harder to circumvent the API.

member.name: P:OpenTracing.Util.GlobalTracer.Instance
member.summary:
Returns the constant .
All methods are forwarded to the currently configured tracer.
Until a tracer is explicitly configured via , the is used.

member.name: M:OpenTracing.Util.GlobalTracer.IsRegistered
member.summary:
Identify whether a has previously been registered.
This check is useful in scenarios where more than one component may be responsible for registering a tracer.
member.returns: Whether a tracer has been registered.

member.name: M:OpenTracing.Util.GlobalTracer.RegisterIfAbsent(OpenTracing.ITracer)
member.summary:
Attempts to register a to back the behaviour of the global tracer ().
Registration is a one-time operation, subsequent attempts do not change the registered global tracer.
member.param: The tracer to use as the global tracer.
member.returns: True if the tracer was successfully registered, otherwise false.

member.name: M:OpenTracing.Util.GlobalTracer.Register(OpenTracing.ITracer)
member.summary:
Register a to back the behaviour of the global tracer ().
Registration is a one-time operation, attempting to call it more often will result in a runtime exception.
Every application intending to use the global tracer is responsible for registering it once during its initialization.
member.param: Tracer to use as global tracer.
